newsitem.title: HONG KONG: More HK workers leave in 1996, return rate falls.
newsitem.headline: More HK workers leave in 1996, return rate falls.

text.p: The emigration rate of Hong Kong workers rose in 1996, the last full year before the British colony returns to Chinese rule, a survey by the Hong Kong Institute of Human Resource Management said on Thursday.
About 0.82 percent of the Hong Kong workforce emigrated last year, up from 0.76 percent in 1995, it said.
Concerns have been repeatedly raised in Hong Kong about a "brain drain" of professionals leaving the colony ahead of the July 1 handover of sovereignty to China.
But many of the emigrants return after obtaining foreign passports, which are seen as a form of insurance for the future.

The returnee rate -- the number of former residents who returned and were recruited in 1996 compared with the number who resigned in order to emigrate -- fell to 54 percent in 1996, down from 60 percent the year before, the institute said.

Most returnees and emigrants fitted a similar profile of professionals or managers with post-secondary school qualifications and aged 33 to 39, it quoted the survey of 180 Hong Kong companies as showing.
The most popular destination for emigrants was Canada, it said.
